document.title: Early Childhood Standards of Quality for Birth to Kindergarten

2452D80829B642ACAD2183A0803217B1.description:
Explain that plants and animals need food and water, but non-living things
like rocks and toy cars do not.

8726E9E96B88447BAE6D11CFE407C9C7.description: Ask a familiar adult if a caterpillar’s chrysalis is a living or non-living thing.

62130C1D92A8478DB8F06397D1850716.description: Mis-identify seeds or coral as “non-living” things.

12E14E0F4FA248A0AA7D3505DFE9D915.description: Sort pictures of plants, animals, and other objects into “living” and “nonliving” categories.

E52FD5AAED424EFFB1163BB7233B92FF.description: Mis-identify a dead plant as a “non-living” thing.

F55D07196B0B437FB5723B55C27B0F9E.description:
Categorize things as “alive” and “not alive,” sometimes. For example,
recognizing that a dog is a living thing, and a toy car is not.

05AF91C7C39F4B46B3EC4BDC0A72D510.description: Sort rocks or leaves by size, color, shape, or texture.

27AA903577BD42549553BF877FEFAC40.description: Participate in a group activity to categorize things as “alive” and “not alive.”

685D83876AEC4414B41D00552FD3BD10.description: Observe, describe, and compare the differences between living and non-living things.

94D4B3BD5037461B8E3BDF330CEDFD3A.description: Watch for animal tracks during an outdoor walk.

616DB73CDFC84FAFAE04865978FAF952.description:
Participate in a group project to draw pictures of animals that live in
their community, to paste where they have been seen on a map of their
community.

FE1126E437C5414988B264241948CA35.description:
Point out a bush on the playground that is the same kind as one in their
aunt’s backyard.

56DBB97E6CFC41618268842779948FDF.description: Identify the basic needs of plants (water, air, sunlight, and nutrients).

61B969425D7F4238AEE5AFD1B3154DBA.description:
Participate in a group discussion about where they have seen deer in their
community.

832AD6E2FF434636BD879C7E180F2D49.description: Tell about the frogs they saw during their visit to the lake.

8DE85DAFF8034696BD9A109AAF42C20F.description: Identify the basic needs of animals (food, water, air, and shelter).

FBBF79527CC645ECA272D660DF9734D8.description:
Explain that the park they like best is the one where they go to watch the big
fish in the pond.

9FED6391240048F08B687044143CDB97.description:
Compare and describe features of the environment, such as identifying one
lake as bigger than another.

CD44D698806E47E7BBA528DADDE73A78.description:
Observe and explore the habitats of a variety of plants and animals in their community (such as
wooded areas, parks, lakes, and streams).

F19E19D01BFC499AB6EB8CBB812FE8A8.description: Watch a deer run through a field and notice that it gallops like a horse.

4ABA94EEB4734FE2B4223D1AA5825573.description:
Describe or identify more details around the characteristics of plants and
animals, such as the breed of a familiar type of dog, the shape of a flower
petal or leaf, more detail around the colors in a butterfly’s wings, etc.

DC5242309C3C4346927B1466B6D29553.description:
Describe a caterpillar they saw outside and ask what kind of butterfly it will
turn into.

A9CB881E0FE54A9981428CFFBBC51FEB.description:
Begin to recognize and discuss the life cycles of different kinds of animals,
such as recognizing that a bird hatches from an egg, but cats give birth to
kittens.

8B975867D41D4D10BB73FC0686D44FBA.description:
Ask about different kinds of flowers, and compare different characteristics of
their seeds (size, color, shape, etc.).

14EAB83CE14B445A824661EE1CFBA138.description:
When drawing a picture of themselves at Halloween, draw trees with orange
and brown leaves.

1F6DBC6304874B779AD2AE49D36BA532.description:
Tell a familiar adult, “The tree’s leaves are red, but they were green before,”
and ask why.

CA2EC87D60E340B1B004E230688456F9.description:
Show interest in caring for the environment, such as asking to care for plants
or animals in the learning environment.

92059EBE84A4419597BCE71783C69EBD.description:
Identify more characteristics of animals and plants, such as the color of the
leaves and flowers of a particular plant, a dog’s ear shape, etc.

843BCAF04F924CB48DA7B81964ACE0A7.description:
With guidance and support, use their fingers to poke holes in soil for planting
seeds.

246437B0C03B4AC28E2D01AD189A71D2.description:
After an adult explains that a tree’s roots help it drink water, pour a cup of
water at the bottom of a tree to “help it drink.”

AA0ED52F1F7C47FCB6464362AA2D6B1A.description: Point at a bird on the playground and announce, “Birds eat worms!”

D847E3C6514A4786A351DE15BB96FDA4.description:
Explore, observe, notice, and describe a variety of plants and animals in their community, and their
life cycles.

48B083F5E58941439CEA2088217F893E.description:
Children show a growing understanding of scientific knowledge related to living and
non-living things.

AC524FD429544C69B5EF645EE03C49BE.description: Categorize types of weather by the seasons they typically happen in.

112E661475E146AE82E72CA841AB7D52.description: Participate in a group routine to chart the changing temperatures.

4D922A3CD86B40E4AF903CF26344E189.description: Point out that the leaves change color before they fall off the tree.

64AF13EDF0BB4636BFBE7621682A0C59.description:
Notice leaves falling from the trees and say that soon it will be time to go to
the apple orchard or pumpkin patch.

210E16DF813045038808B91371762E05.description: Point out the leaves falling in autumn and new buds and sprouts in spring.

26DF1ADF38E543A691C352EC2C599CA2.description: Notice snow on the ground and say, “It’s cold!”

584E78A472D64457A4AA1FE2B1207F59.description: Recognize and make connections between the seasons and their observable characteristics.

F896811F985C4CE7AEB640DF372E27C4.description:
Participate in a group routine to chart how many days each type of weather
has happened.

20DF361A3B504E0AAB38AAB696863CE4.description: Use a weathervane or windsock to figure out which way the wind is blowing.

9CCA3EC730A3401B82FC5062D92FCA06.description:
Describe the weather using more detail, such as “It’s only raining a little bit,”
or “It’s sunny now, but my momma says it’s going to snow later.”

B877E8B350A94F25B1660CC1D8350535.description: Participate in a group routine to identify and record the daily weather.

B61EFB311A294D98A97E3BA78348669D.description:
Identify appropriate clothes for different kinds of weather (shorts for sunny
days, rain jacket for rainy days, heavy coat for cold winter days, etc.).

9763C7960D0E4ECB85897EC55BB31286.description: Participate in a group activity to make a snowman.

8DDC95602CCA42A6B66CBDCAE61B478F.description:
Express disappointment when rain means they won’t be able to play on the
playground.

8B6DFE15374A47689B3DE4B34B281D79.description: Laugh and dance in the rain.

A2A29D9B1A4644478700FD4626AE0F77.description: Ask for sunglasses when it is sunny out.

52B02ADE8B6F4E41A1BB509FFC579DEB.description: Recognize and identify different weather conditions and the ways weather can impact their lives.

9B70D0FFE3FB41FB8006A819F57D4938.description:
Experiment with using soil, water, and other natural materials such as straw
and broken leaves to create mud bricks in an ice cube tray, then build with
them once they dry.

3535C12D428F4FB2BA36BBB5DF2C4FEA.description:
Shake several different kinds of rock in a container until the rocks begin to
grind together and produce new sand and soil, then discuss what happened.

66FEB06EAF6C4AD2815F2B3C8BCF802C.description:
Match color swatches with the different colors of soil and rocks they find on
the playground.

8B763B63D5B646DCB737A931F31D550A.description:
Use a magnifying glass to look closely at the dirt to see and identify grains of
soil, as well as tiny twigs, rocks, and sometimes insects.

25F15EA6D357481582D51FB56F88F66F.description: Sort rocks by size, color, shape, or texture.

974CD03B958F40DB9D511C48338E7F99.description:
Participate in a group activity to identify differences between a collection of
rocks.

6B312FD352974D9B9B4B74EFE473724C.description:
Match color swatches with the different colors of soil and rocks they find on
the playground.

B89B5E5E895B4FF4BA280336F9FC78AC.description:
Explore and recognize a variety of earth materials in their community (soil, rocks, water, etc.) and
their observable properties.

8DD25CE13A4B47838BF6FEBDFF6AA120.description: Children show a growing understanding of the scientific principles related to the earth.

39A93B50C6D14A659F5EE0C5BDD1EF3F.description:
Play an electronic Simon Says game and match the light patterns,
sometimes.

1A207C630B5E462999D7D639D52A9F16.description: Use a desk lamp to make shadow puppets.

51CF4EB02A2C45ED951E49270836C101.description:
Tap different things around the room using rhythm sticks to see how the
sound varies.

9BAA74760B7E42FEBB7D0F872FFDCEFD.description:
Layer red and blue translucent panels over each other on the light table
to make purple.

6EE6CD32696746DD82E5B8231E448B45.description: Ask for sunglasses to shield their eyes from the sunlight.

6D80B5D31A34426DBE137C551FEB662B.description: Use a variety of objects as drums.

8DB333BB767646E790DB882F180AECB3.description: Play with a child-size piano or keyboard.

85BAFD87F8B346BB9CCB9CAFD0E7A7CB.description: Play with toy drums or egg shakers.

FC1D8744D75A43D9867DBE326E956E79.description: Build with translucent colored blocks on the light table.

7CA6E9CAA8BE46E1A67E147B8738C3BD.description: Use the light switch to turn lights on and off.

D71AFD9C4E774261A420912EDABEE74E.description: Observe and explore light and sound.

47FE289B5E724C7BAA2A896D98899731.description: Notice that when rain freezes in cold weather, it turns into ice.

4935BFCEBDC54C0C9EDB3304669FAE56.description:
With adult support, sort and classify items such as a block, a cup
of water, and the air as solids, liquids, or gasses.

93E7EE40107F4BE1AC8A09C355EE5EC4.description:
Work with a group to shake a jar of heavy cream until it turns to
butter.

D4D8C61017B84DEB97AFA083BB20AA01.description: Explain that when ice and snow melt, they both turn into water.

172AF8434C9A42F7934301FE68027C93.description:
Participate in group discussions to identify items that fit into the
categories of solids, liquids, and gasses.

CF28E134000343D084CCE9378DDF8126.description:
Breathe onto a cold window so they can write their name in the
condensation.

E3418E689CDF4D0092B3CCB3005C369E.description: Use their hands to melt ice cubes in the sensory table.

603E3C8536B54B5385848D46E51C36FB.description:
Paint with ice cubes that have been made with drops of food
coloring.

97CF6F74E37D4BA69CB2B670CC4AB4D1.description:
Notice that snow is melting into water, while playing with snow
outdoors or in the sensory table.

D0FC2151460E4A1FB909D18963C376E7.description: Explore and observe the states of matter (liquids, solids, gasses) in their environment.

4467B4EA652B4868A9583CC3B6D7F3F6.description: Explore using a small pulley system to raise and lower toy cars.

87F1BEA4BD6843769748111B430D9CAA.description:
Drop a feather and a baseball from the same height and notice that the
feather falls slower.

F89A34BA8115488D9C651D641F0DF364.description: Build a marble run and make predictions about what pieces they can add to make the marble move faster or slower.

F0EFF1391231471280F6155AD65A6857.description: Build ramps for toy cars and experiment to see which car goes faster down the ramp.

C2A19AD0CFF7496286C698FB88B40032.description:
Explore and compare the ways objects move, including their speed, direction, and duration of
movement.

4B8DA73EC08E447CB63D07EEFAD61CDD.description: Children show a growing understanding of the scientific principles of physical science.

30441B907CEC4A0CBE90E1AD57FD3411.description: Record the height of their seedling in their science journal each day.

E36525A197FB4AAA9DC69141A9A89F1E.description:
Use a bar graph to chart favorite colors in the group and discuss the results
using terms like more, less, and equal.

6C8F339AC6894ABD884BDF18B1F61E27.description: Notice that the clouds are getting darker and say, “I think it’s going to rain.”

C963AC52601040909996206EAEF63877.description:
After being taught that a plant needs moist soil, touch the soil in a potted
plant and ask to water it because it’s dry.

926E6CF1C0F54A969EFAD58994F01D0D.description:
Notice that the classroom fish comes to the surface of the water when
people stand near the tank, and ask, “Why is he doing that?”

B4E7A2946D144ACFBBF67C50DC1678DB.description: Point out the tiny buds beginning to form on trees and plants in the spring.

8DEE8547B0724CF7B37E62702CD6EAAE.description:
Chart different kinds of weather with their group over the course of a week or
a month.

9BCC4C4941EE4A858EB7DBA03CD296CC.description:
Tell stories about the squirrels in their neighborhood eating the jack-o’-
lanterns and playing with the decorations.

0D34149BC23540B3963F54C009714BAB.description: Point out the squirrels gathering nuts and ask why they need so many.

3B1EFF1E99234E8A8D7A3F1961CAEDD1.description:
Chart their predictions about what color flower will grow from the seeds they
planted.

1CE9411D2DBC49778F6E7254639AB149.description:
Say, “It’s sunny–we can go outside!” or look out the window at the rain and
grumble, “But I wanted to go outside.”

599D66F7DF574F67844E658E0AE032CB.description:
Ask to feed the classroom fish when they come to school in the morning
because “it’s breakfast time!” or the fish usually gets fed in the mornings.

8F1DCAFC8E654596B4606BD36239EB6E.description: Communicate and/or record observations, questions, and predictions about their environment.

7059BE1189904EA3821CF99A6EA3B4C2.description: Collect leaves and sort by type of tree and/or leaf shapes.

296A7784148042AC9A8540C4C034A35E.description:
Classify items by their similarities, such as “all of these animals have fur, and
these ones over here have scales!”

CFEE6D791E764CABB65D759D1E181A39.description: Measure the growth of their seedling every day.

1342CEE45D2C436D8DD9155725D88364.description: Sort manipulatives into separate containers during clean up time.

3F069C0BEB6A4041B8BE83792A02C24B.description:
Sort buttons by feel, into piles of fabric-covered buttons and buttons with
holes.

64A784DD639848D48BBEA438BC5BB0EC.description:
Chart different kinds of weather with their group over the course of a week or
a month.

F875E36B09A34B38B5D5453862AA337F.description:
Make marks in their journal as they count how many children have yellow
shirts and green shirts, then compare how many there are of each color.

C772A9E98A63483ABC49655139512CCA.description: Sort animals by habitat (farm or forest, for example).

D00134BB88E84A738AB2D0F8B30A3E08.description:
Talk about cats and dogs and demonstrate an understanding that they are
different.

9584CC85FFF745FDBD70E951931B2ED5.description: Sort blocks by material (plastic/wooden) during clean-up time.

1508238DC4504A93A36184C13D9CA40F.description: Observe, compare, and classify objects and information.

0891ABA601A146F6AA4A85D7BF5C26D8.description: With adult support, mix vinegar into baking soda to make it fizz over the edges of the container like a volcano erupting.

2BE14268DB7D4451834205E22DFA4E38.description:
On a light table, stack a blue translucent square on top of a red one to make
purple.

2FB633F4B9904A9DBB1BC34721D37480.description: Use a flashlight to make shadows with their hands.

D50C65FA3CE9409A81C4CE735061EBBA.description: Melt ice cubes in their hands.

13346E8F90FD47AEB7B263E3A39B5E61.description:
Label the parts of a flower in a drawing, such as stem, petal, roots, and
leaves.

181B4639AE11458AAE8B009DF2799ED9.description:
Use magnifying glasses to observe plants and insects on the playground
and record their observations in a science journal, such as drawing a picture
of a grasshopper and writing, “The grasshopper has long spikey legs.”

F687DEF46D21412B8B04B071264ED1E1.description: Notice the different colors of the birds on the playground.

A2912F4E1EA04F86A7DB70B522FC077F.description:
Draw their observations of a seedling’s growth over time in their science
journal.

9819E4C2A6C74177A7F6C313D4D44A08.description:
Taste several varieties of apples and describe the differences in flavor, color,
and texture.

A665E65322B743F3AF54964D286179D6.description:
Take a nature walk around the outside of the building with an adult and ask
them to identify things.

871AB73ADA374D858F8A9F12DA78200B.description: Notice which side is lower/heavier when weighing rocks on a balance scale.

20FE304228A848B2878E742A4DBB1268.description:
Mix paint colors and notice the new color they create, saying, “I put yellow in
my blue – now it’s green!”

6E0B17DC1C1F46BFA07C413E538C72FD.description:
Wheel around the room with a magnet wand, testing different objects to find
out if they stick (are magnetic), and announce, “The toy car sticks, but the
blocks don’t.”

206E022D8D8B447FB3408E5378DC1D71.description:
Observe and discuss the movement of worms in the sensory table. Say,
“That bug is going over the other one!”

D6E490603E864F92B95DEC00F2416514.description: Build a snowman by stacking lumps of snow.

76C6421116EB47B4B726C81BDFC53C3D.description: Notice snow on the ground and say, “It’s cold!”

8793B20FFCF344509788F63589F83C84.description:
Observe and investigate their environment using scientific thinking, scientific vocabulary, and the
scientific method.

A982C0B21E99446AB44CC6839986D0B9.description: Children explore and demonstrate curiosity about the world around them.
